title: Basics of analytical radiochemistry, decay chains, radionuclide decay, in-growth, radioactive equilibrium etc.

author: Marko Štrok, Reaktorski center, Institut "Jožef Stefan"

segmentation: Hello, my name is Marko and in this lecture I will explain basics of analytical radio chemistry.
Analitica radio chemistry is sort of an ethical chemistry which is dealing with the termination of radioactive elements or radionuclides in different samples.
Radionuclides have specific features which we need to consider when determining them.
First of all, they are already active, which means we have to pay attention to special protection when dealing with high radioactive samples.
We can group radionuclides according to their mode of decay into Alpha, beta, and gamma emitters.
Alpha emitters emit Alpha particle, which is heavy.
Consequently, it interacts stronger with the matter and has lower penetration range.
Beta particle is electron which is smaller and has higher penetration range.
On the contrary, gamma Rays have the higher penetration range.
Projectivity itself can be used for detection of radionuclides and mode of decay is one of the characteristics which governs the detection.
It is worth to remember that radionuclides are present everywhere in the environment.
Although at different activity concentrations.
Radionuclides are the King during the time with their respective half-life to another nuclides which might be stable or radioactive.
Half life is defined as time in which half of radionuclide decays, and is characterized by exponential decrease of the amount of radionuclides.
We usually express the amount of radionuclide activity which has unit becquerel.
This is number of disintegrated nuclides in one second.
Activity of radionuclide in time T can be therefore calculated with this simple exponential equation 1.
Which is, by the way the same as first order reactor kinetics.
Radioactive equilibrium is established between Radium client, which is the case to the Radium client, or so-called, between parent and other radionuclides.
Typical example is secular radioactive equilibrium between strontium 90 and 1890, which is the key product of strontium 19.
It is established after approximately 20 days after separation of Yttrium 90 from strontium 90.
After establishing equilibrium, Yttrium 90 is decaying with half life of strontium 19.

Anthropogenic are result of human activities such as nuclear bumps, Fusion in nuclear reactors and production in cyclotron, for instance.
During the 60s series of nuclear bomb tests releases substantial amounts of anthropogenic radionuclides in the environment as is visible from increase in tritium activity concentration in rainwater.
Other typical anthropogenic radionuclides of interest are strontium 90, cesium 137, cobalt 60.
Another fission products, as well as active nights such as americium 221 and plutonium isotopes.
Natural radionuclides are those produced by other activities except humans.
They can be divided into primordial, which have half life long enough that they did not decay.
Since creation of the Earth.
Typical examples are iranium 238 uranium 235, thorium 232, and potassium 40.

Secondary radionuclides such as Radium 226, lead 210 and polonium 210 are decay products of primordial radionuclides which have shorter half-life but can be found on earth due to radioactive equilibrium with primordial radionuclides.

The geometric determination of radionuclides utilized by radio chemistry mostly consists of either Alpha spectrometry, proportional counting liquid scintillation counting or gamma spectrometry.
Alpha spectrometry is used for the determination of radionuclides which emit Alpha particles during their decay.
Proportional counter can be used either for Alpha or beta emitters.
Its main disadvantage is that it does not enable qualitative determination of Alpha or beta emitters and excellent radiochemical separation before measurements is crucial.
